repnme.cdata!: West Bank and Gaza - Education Action Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for West Bank and Gaza education
            action project were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was substantial, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: Projects aiming to improve planning and public
            financial management have a better chance of succeeding if
            they are part of a broad policy dialogue with central
            ministries, have enough resources to support and monitor the
            proposed actions, and are supported by sufficient donor
            cofinancing resources. Arrangements for progress monitoring
            against project logical framework and key performance
            indicators must be in place and maintained throughout the
            duration of the project. Flexibility in project design and
            implementation are key factors for projects implemented in
            countries in conflict or volatile political contexts. The
            Palestinian education system operates under constant threat
            and therefore has to balance between concurrent and parallel
            emergency and development goals.

5087620.trustfund:
TF027152-PHRD-VOCATIONAL EDUC. &
            TRAINING PROJ.,TF029767-TRUST FUND CREDIT AGREEMENT -
            WEST BANK & GAZA EDUCATION ACTION PROGRAM
5087620.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

repnme.cdata!: West Bank and Gaza - Education Action Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Action Project aims to
            strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Education (MOE)
            to manage the education system more effectively through
            improving policy-making, planning, and budgeting at central
            and district levels. The project consists of two main
            components. The first component, which is made up of two
            sub-components, is to strengthen the capacity of MOE. 1) The
            first sub-component will support the preparation and
            evaluation of Annual Work Plans and Budgets (AWPB) to
            operationalize the priorities of the Five-Year Plan. The
            second sub-component will cover the costs associated with
            improved management of financial and procurement systems to
            implement Trust Fund Credit-funded activities, and the
            hiring of external expertise to support and mentor MOE
            staff. 2) The second main component, Targeted Interventions,
            will support the implementation of activities in the
            Five-Year Plan and AWPB. The subcomponents under this
            component include the extension of a program for school
            improvement, the development of professional standards for
            headteachers, supporting the MOE to develop and pilot the
            curriculum and materials for secondary vocational stream,
            and establishing pilot units for vocational secondary
            classrooms and workshops attached to existing general
            secondary schools.
